instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Hi guys this time I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with no water damage or corrosion. I checked:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>. 3.43v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>. 0v 
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0v 
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3,43v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3,42v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Please confirm the exact model board.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, to allow a higher pulse, if possible.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  3,3V drops to 0 in a second when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered

It only pulsates times

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Do you mean <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is steady high and drops to 0V when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>???

What this means then?
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
I'm sorry my mistake
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulse from 0v to 3.4v  all the time, does not matter trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
When you connect charger, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses in cycle, or just two times?
If pulses at least once, all S3 voltages should pulse at same time.
Also check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and S0 voltages.
Any pulse at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Pulses all the time
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulse  0v to 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> constant voltage 3.33v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulse  0v to 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing too?
If not, check for pulse at pins 5, 6 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Looks like PCH issue, as <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> dpesn't pulse at all.
You should check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Also try known good BIOS, just in case.
